settings.text: Anticonvulsant and anti-epileptic drug Keppra (levetiracetam) is used to treat epilepsy.It reduces the brain's abnormal excitement in order to work.Keppra is prescribed to adults and kids who are at least 4 years old to treat partial onset seizures. This article is written to provide information about Keppra to Welzo users.

Keppra has been demonstrated to be useful in lowering seizure frequency and enhancing quality of life in epilepsy patients.

According to a recent study, Keppra was linked to significant decreases in seizure frequency and enhancements in quality of life indicators, such as mental health, in epilepsy patients.

In a different study, it was discovered that Keppra is just as effective at reducing seizure frequency and enhancing quality of life indicators as topiramate, another anti-epileptic medication.

Keppra may also be useful in the treatment of other conditions, including migraines and bipolar disorder.

Keppra may have some negative effects, such as:

* Tiredness

* Unsteadiness

* Diarrhea

* Migraine

* Irritation

* Depression

* Stress

Please call your doctor if you experience any of these side effects.

Keppra may also result in more severe negative effects, including:

* Allergy symptoms (rash, hives, itching, difficulty breathing, tightness in the chest, swelling of the mouth, face, lips, throat, or tongue); behavioral changes; confusion; coordination issues; dark urine; decreased urination; fever, chills, or sore throat; hallucinations; lower back pain or pain in the legs; memory issues; new or worsening seizures (e.g., increased seizure frequency or severity); severe or persistent headaches; severe or persistent nausea

Adults with partial-onset seizures should begin taking Keppra at a dose of 500 mg twice daily.

The starting dose for kids between the ages of 4 and 16 is 10 mg/kg twice daily.

Adults should not take more than 3 grams of Keppra per day.

The maximum daily dose advised for children is 60 mg/kg.

Take Keppra as soon as you remember if you miss a dose. Skip the missed dose and resume your regular dosing schedule if your next dose is almost due. Never combine two doses at once.

Medication interactions with Keppra include, for instance:

Medication interactions with Keppra include, for instance:

Carbamazepine
The Felbamate
Lamotrigine
Phenytoin
Acid valproate

Keppra works by reducing excessive brain activity.

Although the exact mechanism of Keppra's action is unclear, it is believed to function by preventing the release of the neurotransmitter glutamate. Keppra may help to safeguard neurons from harm by preventing the release of glutamate, which is thought to be involved in neuronal cell death.

Keppra may also control GABA, a neurotransmitter that is crucial for controlling seizures.

Keppra is quickly and completely absorbed when taken orally.

Keppra has a bioavailability of almost 100 percent.

Keppra penetrates the blood-brain barrier and is widely distributed throughout the body.

The kidneys are the main organs that eliminate keppra.

Keppra has a half-life of around 7 hours.
